docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. John C. Lewin, chief executive of the American College of Cardiology, has met with administration officials and members of Congress about ways to revise pay incentives for doctors. He spoke with a blog contributor, Anne Underwood.

headline.main: A New Way to Pay Physicians

docs.abstract: Jack Lewin, chief executive officer of the American College of Cardiology, has a few ideas for changing the physician-payment system.
docs.snippet: Jack Lewin, chief executive officer of the American College of Cardiology, has a few ideas for changing the physician-payment system.

docs.lead_paragraph: Three related issues consumed lawmakers on the Senate Finance Committee as they debated major health care legislation on Wednesday afternoon, but connecting the dots from one controversy to the next isn't easy.

headline.main: Medicare Advantage: Suddenly a Battle With Three Fronts

docs.abstract: On Wednesday afternoon, one amendment before the Senate Finance Committee somehow morphed into a multifocal controversy over care for seniors.
docs.snippet: On Wednesday afternoon, one amendment before the Senate Finance Committee somehow morphed into a multifocal controversy over care for seniors.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lots of readers raised questions (and made angry comments) about my Findings column and post suggesting that the American health care system is not responsible for the relatively low life expectancy of Americans. That conclusion about the longevity gap between the United States and other developed countries came from a new paper by Samuel H. Preston and Jessica Y. Ho of the University of Pennsylvania.
docs.abstract: Readers had lots of questions (and angry comments) about Samuel H. Preston's research on the longevity gap. Here's Dr. Preston's response.
docs.snippet: Readers had lots of questions (and angry comments) about Samuel H. Preston's research on the longevity gap. Here's Dr. Preston's response.

docs.snippet: Talking points for patients and physicians.

headline.main: The Long Search for Fibromyalgia Support
headline.print_headline: The Long Search for Fibromyalgia Support

docs.lead_paragraph: Agenda readers were, well, skeptical when we highlighted a radio story showing that, so far at least, a recent play-or-pay mandate for employers in San Francisco to provide health coverage hasn't led to significant job losses. "Thin reporting," chided "Ted." "Gabi" suspected that the economist studying the program, U.C. Berkeley's Will Dow, was sloppy. "I would suspect that the decrease is there alright, but I'm not seeing it; I'd call it measurement error."

headline.main: Experts Agree: An Employer Mandate Doesn't Cost Many Jobs

docs.abstract: That's because the cost of health insurance is passed on to employees. "There's no economist in the world who disagrees with that," says one conservative expert.
docs.snippet: That's because the cost of health insurance is passed on to employees. "There's no economist in the world who disagrees with that," says one conservative expert.

docs.lead_paragraph: Not many people can lay claim to attempting a "citizen's arrest" of the nation's banking bosses. But it's par for the course for Michael Moore, the controversial film maker whose latest documentary on the financial crisis takes a harsh look at capitalism -- and Wall Street banks like Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, Morgan Stanley, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase.
docs.abstract: Michael Moore, the film maker who tried to make "citizen's arrests" of nation's banking chiefs in "Capitalism: A Love Story," talked with DealBook about his new film and his views on Wall Street.
docs.snippet: Michael Moore, the film maker who tried to make "citizen's arrests" of nation's banking chiefs in "Capitalism: A Love Story," talked with DealBook about his new film and his views on Wall Street.

docs.lead_paragraph: The health care debate is gaining speed as the Senate Finance Committee heads into day two of markups on the proposal offered by its chairman, Max Baucus, and Massachusetts moves closer to filling its vacant Senate seat.

headline.main: The Early Word: Picking Up Momentum

docs.abstract: The health care debate is gaining speed as the Senate Finance Committee heads into day two of markups on the proposal offered by its chairman, Max Baucus, and Massachusetts moves closer to filling its vacant Senate seat.
docs.snippet: The health care debate is gaining speed as the Senate Finance Committee heads into day two of markups on the proposal offered by its chairman, Max Baucus, and Massachusetts moves closer to filling its vacant Senate seat.

byline.original: By ASHLEY SOUTHALL and KATE PHILLIPS

docs.lead_paragraph: The Group of Six is over, done. What's left is the Group of One: Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine.
docs.abstract: With just one Republican on the fence, internal policy squabbles among Senate Democrats will dominate the debate on Wednesday.
docs.snippet: With just one Republican on the fence, internal policy squabbles among Senate Democrats will dominate the debate on Wednesday.
